title: Edward Norton is supported by his wife Shauna Robertson at his Motherless Brooklyn premiere
text:
It took 20 years for Edward Norton to get the Motherless Brooklyn film made.

And on Monday night his passion project film finally made it's debut.

The 50-year-old actor was joined by his wife at costars for the Los Angeles premiere.

Date night: Edward Norton was joined by his wife Shauna Robertson on Monday night as at the premiere of his film Motherless Brooklyn.

The Fight Club star cut a sleek look in a dark blue pinstripe suit and a partially unbuttoned white shirt.

He paired it with black dress shoes, for his big night.

Shauna, a film producer, looked stunning a black lace mini dress and matching heels.

His costar Gugu Mbatha-Raw also stunned on the carpet for the premiere.

Sleek: The Fight Club star cut a sleek look in a dark blue pinstripe suit and a partially unbuttoned white shirt, as his wife was classic in a black lace mini dress

Costars: His costar Gugu Mbatha-Raw also stunned on the carpet for the premiere

The Blackmirror actress went reflective in her strapless gown covered in silver sequins, and tied at the waist with black satin.

She paired it with open toe stilettos and simple diamond earrings.

Mbatha-Raw also stars in AppleTV+'s new drama The Morning Show, which held it's premiere in New York City on the same night.

Choosing favorites: Mbatha-Raw also stars in AppleTV+'s new drama The Morning Show, which held it's premiere in New York City on the same night

Stars came out for the premiere with Seth Rogen, Minnie Driver and Aaron Paul among others.

The Pineapple Express actor looked business casual in a blue suit, a simple ombre mauve t-shirt and white sneakers.

While Driver was classic in a black mini skirt and white puff sleeved blouse.

Also coming out was the Breaking Bad actor, who posed with fellow star Jeff Garlin on the carpet.

Simple look: While Driver was classic in a black mini skirt and white puff sleeved blouse

Leathered up: Aaron Paul wore a black leather jacket and boots

Norton developed, directed, wrote and stars in the film that is released on November 1 in the US.

Based on the 1999 novel of the same name by Jonathan Lethem, with New Line Cinema he acquired the right to the film in the early 2001.

The film is set in 1950's New York, and follows private detective Lionel Essrog (Norton), who notably has Tourette syndrome, as he tries to solve the murder of his mentor.

Friends: He posed with Jeff Garlin

Longtime: Norton developed, directed, wrote and stars in the film that is released on November 1 in the US, after acquiring rights in 2001 from the novel of the same name (pictured Juliette Lewis)

Adapting the film to the 50's, since the novel was set in modern day, and incorporating controversial NYC planner Robert Moses that took Norton the most amount of time.

He told Rolling Stone 'I got blocked for a while and kept picking it back up and putting it away...But I kept coming back to this. There is a certain kind of just, like, discomfort I feel with not completing a thing.'

The Oscar nominee finished the script around 2012 and signed on to direct not long after, but the story of 'about the way the One Percent operate without accountability,' didn't fit the moment, he said.

Mian man: The film is set in 1950's New York, and follows private detective Lionel Essrog (Norton), who notably has Tourette syndrome, as he tries to solve the murder of his mentor (pictured Jack McBrayer)

The author: Jonathan Lethem wrote the novel in 1999

With President Barack Obama entering his second term and 'coastal cognoscenti believed we were entering this post-racial utopia,' his film was out of place.

'Then the 2016 election happened,' he said. Suddenly an underdog battling authoritarian like figures was what audiences could relate to, and wanted.

'I think I needed two decades with it,' he said. 'I don’t think that even 10 years ago I would have had the sense of how important something like empathy would be to our society.'

Adding: 'And the piece really is about empathy. It’s about how we’re all in this together.'
